sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Destination
sci:arg.sci:help:
The name or path name for the destination data. The destination can be a file, a network resource, a data record property, or a global property.
  • Use a network URL for a network resource.
  • Use a file path name for a file.
  • Use "global://property-name" for a global property.

Note:

  • When the destination is a file or network resource, be sure to specify an extension such as .txt or .doc. To save in compressed (zipped) format, add the extension .gz or .zip to the filename.

sci:arg.name: Maximum
sci:arg.sci:help: The maximum number of data records to write (all if value is empty)

sci:arg.name: IfFileExists
sci:arg.sci:help: What to do if the given destination file already exists

sci:arg.name: CharacterEncoding
sci:arg.sci:help:
Indicates the character set that will be used within the file.

ANSI is the default and specifies a character set where each character is defined by a single byte. This allows the Latin-1 (ISO-8859-1) character set to be written to the file. Virtually all applications can read these files.

UTF-8 specifies a variable length character set. Each character is represented by 1 to 6 bytes. This allows writing out all extended characters specified in the Unicode character sets while maintaining reasonably lengthed files. Many applications do not support UTF-8 files.

"Unicode" and "Unicode big endian" are sets where each character is represented by exactly 2 bytes (also known as UCS-2). Depending on which is used will determine the order in which the bytes appear for each character. Many applications do not support Unicode or Unicode big endian files.

For more information about each of these encoding styles, go to http://www.unicode.org/

sci:arg.name: UseByteOrderMark
sci:arg.sci:help:
The byte order mark (BOM) is an optional Unicode character written to the start of a file or data stream that can be used to indicate the character encoding of the following data. Spefically it can be used to indicate the various UTF-8 and UTF-16 encodings.

BOMs are more widely used in a Windows setting. (For example, Windows Notepad includes a BOM in UTF-8 files.)

Setting options are:

Always
For non-ANSI encodings, the BOM is always written at the start of the output stream.
Never
No BOM is written at the start of the output stream.
Native
This is equivalent to "Always" on Windows and "Never" on Linux.

sci:arg.name: BeginningText
sci:arg.sci:help: Text that should precede each record written out.

sci:arg.name: EndingText
sci:arg.sci:help: Any text to be included after each record written out.

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: PropertyNames
sci:arg.sci:help: List of properties to write (separated by commas). "*" indicates to write all properties.

sci:arg.name: IncludePropertyNames
sci:arg.sci:help: Display the name of each property along with its values

sci:arg.name: HierarchyDepth
sci:arg.sci:help: Controls the maximum depth within hierarchical data records to display node and property information. No hierarchical information will be displayed if depth is set to -1. If no value is set, the default is 0.

sci:arg.name: NewlineStyle
sci:arg.sci:help:
Set this value to define the line ending character(s) in the output file. The default value is the Windows-standard carriage return plus line feed (CR+LF), but you may need to change this, especially in a non-Windows environment. Options are:

  • CR+LF (Traditional Windows text file line ending)
  • LF (Line feed, '\n', 0x0A)
  • CR (Carriage return, '\r', 0x0D)
  • Native (CR+LF on Windows, LF on Linux)

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Writes data records to a text file

Data records are formatted as text and written to the file specified by Destination. Each property value is separated by a new line. Separation of data records can be controlled using the parameters under Delimiter Options.

Note:
  • Use HierarchyDepth to control the display of deep properties and nodes from hierarchical data records.
See Also:
  • To write a file formatted with one data record per row with delimiters between the property values, use the Delimited Text Writer.
  • To write out binary data (such as a .png file), use the Binary Writer.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: CommandLine
sci:arg.sci:help: Command line for application or file to execute on the client machine.

sci:arg.name: Result Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: Parameters for assigning results to properties.

sci:arg.name: StdinProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: Defines the property name that holds the desired value of the program's standard input (stdin). Denote a global property with a leading @ character. Note that this property can only be defined if WaitForExit is set to True.

sci:arg.name: StdoutProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: Defines the property name that will hold the program's standard output (stdout). Denote a global property with a leading @ character. Note that this property can only be defined if WaitForExit is set to True.

sci:arg.name: StderrProperty
sci:arg.sci:help: Defines the property name that will hold the program's standard error (stderr). Denote a global property with a leading @ character. Note that this property can only be defined if WaitForExit is set to True.

sci:arg.name: PropertyForExitStatus
sci:arg.sci:help: A property may be defined to hold the value of the program exit status code. Denote a global property with a leading @ character. Note that this property can only be defined if WaitForExit is set to True.

sci:arg.name: Additional Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Contains less commonly used parameters

sci:arg.name: WaitForExit
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to wait for the program to finish before returning from the process call. This parameter must be set to True for StdinProperty, StdoutProperty, StderrProperty, or PropertyForExitStatus to function.

sci:arg.name: Environment
sci:arg.sci:help:
Specifies additional environment variable settings that will be used by the spawned process. Specify each setting on a line by itself as
variable=name

The spawned process will inherit the existing environment of the protocol job process, and any settings here will be appended to the variable list. To make use of an existing variable, surround the variable name with percent signs (e.g. to prepend, use something like
PATH=c:\mydir;%PATH%

Since this will run on the Windows client, all environment variables are case insensitive.

sci:arg.name: UseCommandInterpreter
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether or not to prepend "cmd.exe /c" to the command line.

sci:arg.name: ConsoleMode
sci:arg.sci:help: Specifies the console window behavior. It only applies if UseCommandInterpreter is set to 'True' and StdinProperty, StdoutProperty, and StderrProperty are not defined. 'Hide' prevents the console from being displayed. 'Show' displays the console window for program output. 'ShowAndKeepOpen' leaves the console window on the screen after the program finishes.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Componet Attributes

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Runs a Windows command line application on the client machine.

Define the command line by entering text as you would in a command prompt window. The component includes facilities for looking up a program name in the Windows registry. It can interpret a program name as a ProgID, such as "InternetExplorer.Application", or as a shell command, such as "IsisServer", or as a document to load into an associated program, such as "c:\spreadsheet.xls".

CommandLine: The command that the component will run. The correct syntax is the full command line exactly as you would type it in a shell command window. The first space- or quote-delimited item of the command line can be a ProgId, such as "InternetExplorer.Application". This starts up Internet Explorer (IE) without having to specify the path to IE explicitly. Shell command associations are also supported, so "IsisServer" will start Isis Draw. Finally, there is support for file associations, so the path "D:\docs\notes.doc" will start Microsoft Word and load the specified document.

WaitForExit: When TRUE, the data pipeline is blocked until the command has completed.

PropertyForExitStatus: Allows you to assign the exit status of the command to a global property or to a data record property. Use either a global or local property reference, such as @status or status.

StdinProperty, StdoutProperty, and StderrProperty: Allows you to redirect standard communications to global properties or to data record properties. Use either a global or local property reference, such as @stdin or stdin.

Environment: Specifies additional environment variable settings that will be used by the spawned process. Specify each setting on a line by itself as "variable=name". The spawned process will inherit the existing environment of the PipelinePilot process, and any settings defined here will be appended to the variable list. To make use of an existing variable, surround the variable name with percent signs (e.g. "PATH=c:\mydir;%PATH%"). Since this will run on the Windows client, all environment variables are case insensitive.

UseCommandInterpreter: When True, parses the command line through the windows interpreter cmd.exe. In particular, this needs to be set to True if the CommandLine utilizes standard output or input redirection (such as cmd.exe /c "c:\Program Files\R\rterm.exe" "0<$(CommandFile)").

Notes:

  • If your command line includes a file path, create a new parameter for the component, of type URL, so the user can enter the path. Then use a token replacement in the CommandLine to pick up the value. For example: Notepad.exe "$(SciTegicRoot)\$(Path)".
  • When the component is separated from any other pipeline, the command line is run just once.
  • You can add an input or output pass port to the component, to integrate it with a pipeline. If there is an output port, but no input port, the command is run once and a single new record is generated. If there is an input port, then the command is run once for each data record passed in.

See Also:

Command-line Integration Guide

UseCommandInterpreter: When True, parses the command line through the windows interpreter cmd.exe. In particular, this needs to be set to True if the CommandLine utilizes standard output or input redirection (such as cmd.exe /c "c:\Program Files\R\rterm.exe" "0<$(CommandFile)").

Notes:

  • If your command line includes a file path, create a new parameter for the component, of type URL, so the user can enter the path. Then use a token replacement in the CommandLine to pick up the value. For example: Notepad.exe "$(SciTegicRoot)\$(Path)".
  • When the component is separated from any other pipeline, the command line is run just once.
  • You can add an input or output pass port to the component, to integrate it with a pipeline. If there is an output port, but no input port, the command is run once and a single new record is generated. If there is an input port, then the command is run once for each data record passed in.

See Also:

Command-line Integration Guide
